{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3418631,"name":"","username":"Aiden_m","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T01:51:24.189Z","cooked":"

We recently assembled our Swerve XS modules, and one of the steering pinions has a wobble too it, the pinion is pressed on all the way and the gears are meshing properly but it still wobbles, will this affect the way the swerve will work, and is it unsafe or could it pose a risk to our swerves if we left it on like that.
below are a bottom profile video and a side profile video, sorry about all the sounds and bad camera angles, I filmed them during another class and without a table
NOTE: The gears have not been greased yet so they don’t sounds super smooth, but you can still here the wobbly pinions
Swerve xs bottom view (youtube.com)
Swerve XS side profile (youtube.com)
Thank you!!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T01:51:24.189Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":40,"reads":363,"readers_count":362,"score":272.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470369,"topic_slug":"pinion-wobble","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/shorts/4AiiFwWlAig","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":58},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/shorts/Rw19O5zRvEc","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":45}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64630,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pinion-wobble/470369/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3418633,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T02:03:47.948Z","cooked":"

First off, good catch.

Second, not healthy.

The pinion gear, with its dedendum modification will mesh readily, despite the misalignment. This is probably why it spins ok without binding.

From your video (botom view) it looks like the pinion (motor) shaft is bent, rather than the pinion being bored incorrectly. This is what I am willing to put my money on especially if it is a used motor.

Can you give us an idea of if the gears seem looser/tighter at different points as you steer the module? This may be hard to feel due to all the reduction, so you may be better spinning the neo550 by hand.

What do the other modules look like? If thwy all wobble the same amount it is highly likely to be an assembly or manufacturing defect. If it is just the one it is likely an assembly issue (i.e. something was dropped or pressed wrong). (Not trying to attribute blame here, just looking for a source of the problem)

Easy test remove the motor how does the module spin? If it’s smooth then from the video it looks like your motor shaft is bent/unconcentric.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-08-28T05:46:15.171Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":282,"readers_count":281,"score":71.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470369,"topic_slug":"pinion-wobble","display_username":"R.C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9979,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pinion-wobble/470369/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3418692,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-28T13:45:33.416Z","cooked":"

Most likely the shaft bent on the NEO 550 when pressing the pinion. We have had this time to time when the interface between the pinion and the shaft is too tight to to variation in the parts, especially with the very small 550 shaft its risky. One of the challenges with using parts from different suppliers is press fits, e.g. I know older NEO 550s used to be undersized and it was the opposite issue.

I’d personally replace it so you don’t excessively wear the module teeth.

This module is way less smooth from the motor than all the others are, all of the other modules do not wobble like this one but still wobble a tiny bit but it’s barely noticeable, this module is the only module with a slightly used 550 due to someone mixing up the used one and a new one

Issue is probably the 550… Take off all motors and verify the modules spin. If that’s smooth you’ll need to figure which 550s are the worst and replace them/press those pinion on better.

Yes all the modules spin well, we’re going to replace the 550 that is bent

Try swapping steering motors with a different module, at this point the community concensus is on a bent shaft.

This bent shaft will impact software tuning and gear life at minimum. Very likely you will need to replace this motor unfortunately.
